4.2 GEOMETRY.PY FILE - THE NODE CLASS

Class Definition * The Node class is a component in a graph structure, it will be used for proving geometric theorems and/or other similar tasks. * The docstring explains that nodes can represent various geometric entities and maintain relationships with other nodes. High Level ELI5 Analogy * Let's use an analogy of a social network to explain the Node class. * As such, we imagine each `**Node**` as a **person** in a social network. * This network isn't just about who knows whom, but also includes details about friendships merging, people representing groups, and different types of relationships. Constructor and Attributes * The **`__init__`** method initializes a Node instance. * It sets up various attributes as shown in the table below: | **Attribute** | **Type** | **Purpose in Node Class** | **Social Network Analogy** | |-------------------|-------------|-----------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------| | **`self.name`** | **`str`** | Represents the name of the node. | Like a person's name in the social network. If they don't have a name, they use a unique ID. | | **`self.graph`** | **`Any`** | Reference to the graph this node is part of. | Represents the social network platform or community the person belongs to. | | **`self.edge_graph`** | **`dict`** | Tracks connections to other nodes. | A list of the person's friends and the details about how and why they are friends (shared interests, etc.). | | **`self.merge_graph`**| **`dict`** | Maintains history of merges with other nodes. | History of when and why two people (one of which is the person) decided to represent themselves as a single entity (like a couple or a team). | | **`self.rep_by`** | **`Node`**/**`None`** | Indicates which node this node is represented by. | If a person is part of a group or team, this shows who is the spokesperson or leader of that group. | | **`self.members`** | **`set`** | Set of nodes in the equivalence class this node belongs to. | Members of a group or community that the person is part of. | | **`self._val`** | **`Node`**/**`None`** | Private attribute for value-type relationships. | Represents a specific quality or characteristic of a/the person, like their role in a project. | | **`self._obj`** | **`Node`**/**`None`** | Private attribute for object-type relationships. | The actual project or object that is associated with the person's role. | | **`self.deps`** | **`list`** | List of dependencies. | Other people or things that this person relies on or is influenced by. | | **`self.num`** | **`Numeric`**/**`None`** | Numerical representation of the node. | A unique number or ID for the person, used for sorting or identification purposes. | | **`self.change`** | **`set`** | Tracks nodes dependent on this node's numerical representation. | People who are influenced or affected by changes in this person's status or role. |

class Node: """ Represents a node in a proof state graph, which can be a Point, Line, Circle, etc. This class handles the complexities of graph-based relationships, including merging histories, equivalence relationships, and connections to other nodes. Attributes: name (str): The name of the node. Defaults to the object's string representation if empty. graph (Any): A reference to the graph that this node is a part of. edge_graph (dict): A dictionary representing connections to other nodes. merge_graph (dict): A dictionary maintaining the history of merges with other nodes. rep_by (Node or None): The node that this node is currently represented by, if any. members (set): A set of nodes that are members of the equivalence class this node belongs to. _val (Node or None): A private attribute for value-type relationships. _obj (Node or None): A private attribute for object-type relationships. deps (list): A list of dependencies. num (numeric or None): A numerical representation of the node, used for indexing or sorting. change (set): A set of nodes whose numerical representation depends on this node. Example Usage: >>> point = Node(name="PointA") >>> line = Node(name="LineB") >>> point.connect_to(line, deps=["dependency1"]) """ def __init__(self, name: str = '', graph: Any = None): """ Initialize a new Node instance. Args: name (str): The name of the node. If not provided, defaults to the object's string representation. graph (Any): The graph to which this node belongs. Can be any type. """ self.name = name or str(self) # Use the provided name or default to the object's string representation. self.graph = graph # The graph this node is part of. Could be any structure or type. # Edge graph: Tracks what other nodes this node is connected to. # Structure: # edge_graph = { # other_node1: { # this_node1: deps, # this_node2: deps # }, # other_node2: { # this_node2: deps, # ... # } # } self.edge_graph = {} # Merge graph: Keeps the history of merges with other nodes. # Structure: # merge_graph = { # this_node1: { # merged_node1: deps1, # merged_node2: deps2 # }, # ... # } self.merge_graph = {} self.rep_by = None # The node that this node is represented by, if any. self.members = {self} # Starts as a set containing only this node, representing its equivalence class. self._val = None # Private attribute for storing a value-type relationship (like length or angle). self._obj = None # Private attribute for storing an object-type relationship. self.deps = [] # A list to track dependencies. # Numerical representation, possibly for indexing or sorting purposes within the graph. self.num = None # Set of nodes whose numerical representation ('num') is influenced by this node. self.change = set() def set_rep(self, node: 'Node') -> None: """ Set another node as the representative of this node. This method is used when two nodes are determined to be equivalent, and one needs to act as the representative. Args: node (Node): The node to set as the representative. Example Usage: >>> node1 = Node(name="Node1") >>> node2 = Node(name="Node2") >>> node1.set_rep(node2) # Node2 now represents Node1 Raises: ValueError: If the provided node is the same as the current node. """ if node == self: raise ValueError("A node cannot represent itself.") # Set the representative node. self.rep_by = node # Merge the edge graph of the current node with the representative node. # - This means combining their connections. node.merge_edge_graph(self.edge_graph) # Update the representative's members set to include members of this node. # - This reflects that they are now part of the same equivalence class. node.members.update(self.members) def rep(self) -> 'Node': """ Get the representative node of this node. If this node is part of an equivalence class (i.e., it has been merged with other nodes), this method will return the node that represents this equivalence class. Returns: Node: The representative node. Example Usage: >>> node = Node(name="Node") >>> rep_node = node.rep() # Get the representative of 'node' """ x = self # Traverse up the chain of representatives. # - This is akin to finding the "root" or the primary representative in the equivalence class. while x.rep_by: x = x.rep_by return x def why_rep(self) -> list[Any]: """ Explains the reason(s) why this node is represented by its current representative. This method utilizes the 'why_equal' method to trace back the series of merges or equivalences that led to the current representation of this node. Returns: list[Any]: A list of reasons (dependencies) explaining the representative relationship. Example Usage: >>> node1 = Node(name="Node1") >>> node2 = Node(name="Node2") >>> node1.set_rep(node2) >>> node1.why_rep() # Explains why node1 is represented by node2 """ # The method leverages the 'why_equal' function, passing the current representative node. return self.why_equal([self.rep()], None) def rep_and_why(self) -> tuple[Node, list[Any]]: """ Retrieves the representative of this node and the reasons for its representation. This method combines the functionality of 'rep' and 'why_rep' to provide both the representative node and the reasons behind this representation in a single call. Returns: tuple[Node, list[Any]]: A tuple containing the representative node and a list of reasons for the representation. Example Usage: >>> node = Node(name="Node") >>> rep, reasons = node.rep_and_why() # Get the representative and the reasons """ # First, find the representative node of this node. rep = self.rep() # Then, get the reasons why this node is represented by the rep node. # - This is done by tracing back the equivalence or merging history. return rep, self.why_equal([rep], None) def neighbors(self, oftype: Type[Node], return_set: bool = False, do_rep: bool = True) -> list[Node]: """ Retrieves a list of neighboring nodes of a specific type. This method can return either direct neighbors or representatives of those neighbors, depending on the 'do_rep' flag. Args: oftype (Type[Node]): The type of neighboring nodes to retrieve. return_set (bool): If True, returns a set instead of a list. Defaults to False. do_rep (bool): If True, returns representatives of the neighbors. Defaults to True. Returns: list[Node]: A list (or set, if return_set is True) of neighboring nodes or their representatives. Example Usage: >>> node = Node(name="Node") >>> neighbors = node.neighbors(Node, return_set=False, do_rep=True) """ # Initialize the set of neighboring nodes (or their representatives) result = set() # Determine whether to use the representative of this node or the node itself. rep = self.rep() if do_rep else self # Iterate through each neighbor in the edge graph of the representative (or this node). for n in rep.edge_graph: # Check if the neighbor matches the specified type, if type is given. if oftype is None or isinstance(n, oftype): # Add either the representative of the neighbor or the neighbor itself to the result. result.add(n.rep() if do_rep else n) # Return the result as a set if specified, otherwise as a list. return result if return_set else list(result) def merge_edge_graph(self, new_edge_graph: dict[Node, dict[Node, list[Node]]]) -> None: """ Merges a new edge graph into this node's existing edge graph. This method is essential for combining the connections (edges) of two nodes when they are merged, ensuring that the merged node maintains all existing connections. Args: new_edge_graph (dict): The edge graph to be merged with this node's edge graph. Example Usage: >>> node1 = Node(name="Node1") >>> node2 = Node(name="Node2") >>> node1.merge_edge_graph(node2.edge_graph) """ for x, xdict in new_edge_graph.items(): # Iterate through each node and its associated dictionary in the new edge graph. if x in self.edge_graph: # If this node already exists in our edge graph, update its dependencies. self.edge_graph[x].update(dict(xdict)) else: # If this node is new to our edge graph, add it along with its dependencies. self.edge_graph[x] = dict(xdict) def merge(self, nodes: list[Node], deps: list[Any]) -> None: """ Merges a list of nodes into this node, updating the merge graph. Each node in the list will be merged with this node, and the dependencies for each merge will be recorded. Args: nodes (list[Node]): The nodes to merge with this node. deps (list[Any]): The dependencies associated with each merge. Example Usage: >>> node1 = Node(name="Node1") >>> node2 = Node(name="Node2") >>> node3 = Node(name="Node3") >>> node1.merge([node2, node3], deps=["dep1", "dep2"]) """ # Merge each node in the list with this node ... one by one for node in nodes: self.merge_one(node, deps) def merge_one(self, node: Node, deps: list[Any]) -> None: """ Merges a single node into this node, updating the merge graph. This method is used for merging one node at a time, setting this node as the representative for the merged node and recording the dependencies for the merge. Args: node (Node): The node to be merged with this node. deps (list[Any]): The dependencies associated with the merge. Example Usage: >>> node1 = Node(name="Node1") >>> node2 = Node(name="Node2") >>> node1.merge_one(node2, deps=["dep1"]) """ # Update the representative of the node to be this node's representative. node_rep = node.rep() node_rep.set_rep(self.rep()) if node in self.merge_graph: # If the node is already merged, no further action is required. return # Update the merge graph for both nodes to reflect the new dependencies. # - The node we are bringing in and the node we represent (self) self.merge_graph[node] = deps node.merge_graph[self] = deps def is_val(self, node: Node) -> bool: """ Checks if the relationship between this node and another node is of a specific value type. This method is used to determine if there's a specific value-type relationship between two nodes. Some examples of this are: - a `Line` (self) and a `Direction` (node) - a `Segment` (self) and a `Length` (node) - an `Angle` (self) and a `Measure` (node) - a `Ratio` (self) and a `Value` (node) Args: node (Node): The other node to check the relationship with. Returns: bool: True if there is a value-type relationship, False otherwise. Example Usage: >>> line = Node(name="Line") >>> direction = Node(name="Direction") >>> line.is_val(direction) # Returns True if 'direction' is a value-type for 'line' """ # The following checks are specific to the types of nodes and their value relationships. # - This is typically used in geometric or other domain-specific contexts. # - If none of the following relationships are matched than we return False. return ( # Is this node a Line and is the other node a Direction (isinstance(self, Line) and isinstance(node, Direction)) or # Is this node a Segment and the other node is a Length (isinstance(self, Segment) and isinstance(node, Length)) or # Is this node an Angle and the other node is a Measure (isinstance(self, Angle) and isinstance(node, Measure)) or # Is this node a Ratio and the other node is a Value (isinstance(self, Ratio) and isinstance(node, Value)) ) def set_val(self, node: Node) -> None: """ Sets a node as the value-type relationship of this node. This method is used when you want to associate a value-type relationship with this node, like associating a Length (value not the object) with a Segment. Args: node (Node): The node to set as the value-type relationship. Example Usage: >>> segment = Node(name="Segment") >>> length = Node(name="Length") >>> segment.set_val(length) # Sets 'length' as the value for 'segment' """ self._val = node # Set the provided node as the value-type relationship. def set_obj(self, node: Node) -> None: """ Sets a node as the object-type relationship of this node. This method is similar to 'set_val' but is used for setting object-type relationships. For example, associating a Segment with a Length. Args: node (Node): The node to set as the object-type relationship. Example Usage: >>> length = Node(name="Length") >>> segment = Node(name="Segment") >>> length.set_obj(segment) # Sets 'segment' as the object for 'length' """ self._obj = node # Set the provided node as the object-type relationship. # Properties are defined to give easy access to the value and object relationships. @property def val(self) -> Node: """ A property to get the node representing the value-type relationship of this node. Returns the representative of the value-type node if it exists, otherwise None. Returns: Node or None: The representative of the value-type relationship node. Example usage: >>> segment = Node(name="Segment") >>> length = Node(name="Length") >>> segment.set_val(length) >>> segment.val # Returns the representative of 'length' """ return self._val.rep() if self._val else None @property def obj(self) -> Node: """ A property to get the node representing the object-type relationship of this node. Returns the representative of the object-type node if it exists, otherwise None. Returns: Node or None: The representative of the object-type relationship node. Example Usage: >>> length = Node(name="Length") >>> segment = Node(name="Segment") >>> length.set_obj(segment) >>> length.obj # Returns the representative of 'segment' """ return self._obj.rep() if self._obj else None def equivs(self) -> set[Node]: """ Retrieves all nodes that are equivalent to this node. This method returns all the members of the equivalence class that this node belongs to, including itself. Returns: set[Node]: A set of nodes that are equivalent to this node. Example usage: >>> node = Node(name="Node") >>> equivalent_nodes = node.equivs() """ # Retrieve the representative of this node and return all its members. # - This will represent the equivalence class of this node. return self.rep().members def connect_to(self, node: Node, deps: list[Any] = None) -> None: """ Connects this node to another node, updating the edge graph. This method is used to establish a connection or relationship between this node and another, optionally with a list of dependencies that describe the nature of the connection. Args: node (Node): The node to connect to. deps (list[Any], optional): The dependencies associated with the connection. Example Usage: >>> node1 = Node(name="Node1") >>> node2 = Node(name="Node2") >>> node1.connect_to(node2, deps=["dependency1"]) """ # Get the representative of this node. rep = self.rep() if node in rep.edge_graph: # If there's already a connection to the node, update the dependencies. rep.edge_graph[node].update({self: deps}) else: # If this is a new connection, add it to the edge graph with the dependencies. rep.edge_graph[node] = {self: deps} if self.is_val(node): # If there is a value-type relationship between this node and the other... set it accordingly. self.set_val(node) node.set_obj(self) def equivs_upto(self, level: int) -> dict[Node, Node]: """ Retrieves the equivalent nodes up to a certain level of depth in the merge graph. This method is useful for understanding the depth of equivalence relationships between nodes. - This mechanism is essential for understanding the node's equivalence relationships up to a certain depth Details: - A breadth-first search (BFS) approach is employed to traverse the merge_graph. - The queue is used to process each node in a level-by-level manner. - For each node, its neighbors (other nodes it's merged with) are examined. - The traversal considers the 'level' of the merge relationship, allowing control over how deep the search goes in the graph. Args: level (int): The level up to which equivalent nodes should be retrieved. Returns: dict[Node, Node]: A dictionary where keys are nodes and values are their parents in the merge graph up to the specified level. Example Usage: >>> node = Node(name="Node") >>> equivalents_up_to_level = node.equivs_upto(2) """ parent = {self: None} # Start with the current node as its own parent. visited = set() # Keep track of visited nodes. queue = [self] # Queue for BFS traversal. i = 0 while i < len(queue): # Get the current node from the queue. current = queue[i] i += 1 # Increment the index for the next iteration. # Mark the current node as visited to avoid reprocessing it. visited.add(current) # Iterate through each neighbor connected to the current node in the merge graph. for neighbor in current.merge_graph: # Check if the level of the merge relationship is within the specified limit. # If the level is too high (i.e., exceeds the specified 'level'), skip this neighbor. if level is not None and current.merge_graph[neighbor].level is not None and current.merge_graph[neighbor].level >= level: continue # If this neighbor hasn't been visited yet, add it to the queue for processing. if neighbor not in visited: queue.append(neighbor) # Record the parent (current node) of this neighbor. This is useful for backtracking. parent[neighbor] = current return parent def why_equal(self, others: list[Node], level: int) -> list[Any]: """ Explains why this node is considered equal to other nodes, up to a certain level. This method performs a breadth-first search (BFS) in the merge graph to find the path to the specified nodes, considering the level of merges. Args: others (list[Node]): The nodes to compare with. level (int): The level up to which the search is performed. Returns: list[Any]: A list of reasons (dependencies) explaining why the nodes are considered equal. Example Usage: >>> node1 = Node(name="Node1") >>> node2 = Node(name="Node2") >>> reasons = node1.why_equal([node2], level=2) """ # Convert the list of other nodes to a set for efficient look-up. others = set(others) # Initialize the counter for the number of 'other' nodes found. found = 0 # Initialize the dictionary to keep track of each node's parent in the BFS tree. parent = {} # Initialize the BFS queue with the current node. queue = [self] # Initialize the index for iterating over the queue. i = 0 # Iterate until the queue is exhausted while i < len(queue): current = queue[i] # Get the current node from the queue. if current in others: # If the current node is one of the 'others', increment the found counter. found += 1 if found == len(others): # If all 'other' nodes are found, break out of the loop. break i += 1 # Move to the next node in the queue. # Iterate over the neighbors of the current node in the merge graph. for neighbor in current.merge_graph: # Check if the merge level of the neighbor is within the specified limit. if level is not None and current.merge_graph[neighbor].level is not None and current.merge_graph[neighbor].level >= level: continue # Skip neighbors beyond the specified level. if neighbor not in parent: # If the neighbor hasn't been visited yet, add it to the queue and record its parent. queue.append(neighbor) parent[neighbor] = current # Perform backtracking from the found nodes to the current node, # - This uses the parent dictionary to find the path and reasons for equality. return bfs_backtrack(self, others, parent) def why_equal_groups(self, groups: list[list[Node]], level: int) -> tuple[list[Any], list[Node]]: """ Performs a breadth-first search (BFS) to determine why this node is equal to at least one member of each group. This method is useful for understanding complex equivalence relationships across multiple groups of nodes, particularly in scenarios where a node might be equivalent to different nodes in different contexts. Args: groups (list[list[Node]]): A list of groups, each containing multiple nodes. level (int): The level up to which the search is conducted in the merge graph. Returns: tuple[list[Any], list[Node]]: A tuple containing a list of reasons for equivalence and a list of equivalent nodes from each group. Example Usage: >>> node = Node(name="Node") >>> group1 = [Node(name="Node1"), Node(name="Node2")] >>> group2 = [Node(name="Node3"), Node(name="Node4")] >>> reasons, equivalents = node.why_equal_groups([group1, group2], level=2) """ # Initialize a list to hold the found equivalent node in each group. others = [None for _ in groups] # Initialize the counter for the number of groups where an equivalent node is found. found = 0 # Initialize the dictionary to track the parent of each node in the BFS tree. parent = {} # Initialize the queue for BFS, starting with the current node. queue = [self] # Initialize the index for iterating over the queue. i = 0 # Iterate until the queue is exhausted while i < len(queue): current = queue[i] # Check each group for an equivalent node. for j, grp in enumerate(groups): if others[j] is None and current in grp: others[j] = current # Record the equivalent node found in this group. found += 1 # Increment the counter for found groups. if found == len(others): # If equivalents are found in all groups, stop the search. break i += 1 # Process the neighbors of the current node in the merge graph. for neighbor in current.merge_graph: # Only consider neighbors within the specified level. if level is not None and current.merge_graph[neighbor].level is not None and current.merge_graph[neighbor].level >= level: continue # Only consider neighbors not already contained within the parent if neighbor not in parent: queue.append(neighbor) parent[neighbor] = current # Backtrack from the found nodes to determine the path and reasons for equivalence. return bfs_backtrack(self, others, parent), others def why_val(self, level: int) -> list[Any]: """ Explains why the value of this node is considered equal to its current value, up to a certain level. This method is useful for understanding the reasoning behind the value assignment of this node, especially in complex graphs where values are determined through a series of equivalences. Args: level (int): The level up to which the search for equivalence is performed. Returns: list[Any]: A list of reasons (dependencies) explaining the value equivalence. Example Usage: >>> node = Node(name="Node") >>> value_node = Node(name="ValueNode") >>> node.set_val(value_node) >>> reasons = node.why_val(level=2) """ # If there are no values assigned we exit early and return None. if self._val is None: return None # Perform a BFS to find the reason why this node's value is equal to the representative of its value. return self._val.why_equal([self.val], level) def why_connect(self, node: Node, level: int = None) -> list[Any]: """ Explains the reasons behind the connection between this node and another node, up to a certain level. This method is particularly useful in scenarios where the graph represents complex interdependencies, and understanding these connections is crucial. Args: node (Node): The node to which the connection is established. level (int, optional): The level up to which the search is conducted in the edge graph. Returns: list[Any]: A list of dependencies explaining the connection to the specified node. Example Usage: >>> node1 = Node(name="Node1") >>> node2 = Node(name="Node2") >>> node1.connect_to(node2, deps=["dependency1"]) >>> reasons = node1.why_connect(node2, level=2) """ # Get the representative of this node. rep = self.rep() # Get the representative of this node. # Get the list which contains all the nodes that are connected to the specified node vai the rep's edge_graph equivs = list(rep.edge_graph[node].keys()) # Return None if there are no equivalent connections. if not equivs: return None # Consider the first equivalent node for simplicity. equiv = equivs[0] # Find the reasons/dependencies for the equivalence/connection between this node and the specified node. dep = rep.edge_graph[node][equiv] return [dep] + self.why_equal(equiv, level)

4.3 GEOMETRY.PY FILE - THE NODE CLASS

The Remaining Class Definitions * Each subclass represents different geometric concepts. * These classes inherit from Node and have additional methods specific to their geometric nature. * The actual geometric concepts that are created as subclasses are: * **`Point`** / **`Node`** * A basic unit in geometry, representing a location in space with no implicit size or dimension. * **`Line`** * A line is an **infinitely long** (otherwise it would be a **segment**, straight path with no thickness. * It's a fundamental concept because it's used to define other geometric figures, and many theorems in Euclidean Geometry are based on the properties of lines. * **`Segment`** * A segment is a part of a line that is bounded by two distinct end points. * Segments are important because they represent the simplest form of a measurable distance in geometry. * **`Circle`** * A circle is a set of points in a plane that are all at a given distance (the radius) from a fixed point (the center). * Circles are crucial in geometry due to their symmetry and the way they relate to other geometric figures like lines and angles. * **`Angle`** * An angle is formed by two rays (or line segments) with a common endpoint. * Angles are a fundamental measure of the rotation between two intersecting lines and are key to understanding geometric properties and relationships. * Angles help us define more complication geometric concepts (planes, etc) * **`Ratio`** * In geometry, ratios are used to compare sizes of similar figures, lengths of sides, and other quantities. * Ratios are fundamental in understanding proportions and scaling in geometry, as well as in trigonometry. * **`Direction`** * Refers to the course along which something moves or faces. * In geometry, direction can be represented as vectors or through angular relationships. * **`Measure`** and **`Length`** * Understanding how to quantify or measure geometrical entities. * Length typically refers to the distance between two points/nodes * Measure is similar but usually extends to Angle(s), Area(s), etc. * **`Angle`** * Formed by two rays (or lines) that share a common endpoint. * Understanding how angles are measured and their properties is important. Resources for Fundamentals of Euclidean Geometry * Mathematics LibreTexts: * This resource offers detailed explanations of the basic concepts in Euclidean geometry. * It covers the definitions and properties of points, lines, planes, angles, and various geometric figures, which are essential for understanding the structure and relationships in Euclidean space. * It also discusses **Euclid's five postulates** (discussed above), which are the foundational assumptions of this field. * This is a great resource for learning about the core elements of Euclidean Geometry in a structured manne. * BYJU'S Euclidean Geometry: * This is an educational resource that provides an overview of Euclidean geometry. * It covers the study of geometrical shapes and figures based on different axioms and theorems, primarily focusing on flat or plane surfaces (similar to the topic of AlphaGeometry). * The resource also touches upon the historical context of Euclidean geometry, its development, and its foundational elements like points, lines, and planes. * I found this one useful for understanding the practical applications and historical significance of Euclidean Geometry. * Britannica on Euclidean Geometry: * This article provides a summary of Euclidean geometry, emphasizing its role as the study of plane and solid figures based on axioms and theorems used by the Greek mathematician Euclid. * It underlines the importance of fundamental concepts like points, lines, angles, and circles in forming the basis of Euclidean geometry (very similar to what we are doing next). * The resource is valuable for those looking to understand the broader context and impact of Euclidean geometry in the field of mathematics.
Graph Networking Concepts * **Node (Vertex)** * A fundamental unit in a graph network, representing an entity (e.g., a point, line, circle, etc. ***in geometry***). * **Edge** * Represents the relationship or connection between two nodes in a graph. * **Graph Traversal**: * The process of visiting, checking, and/or updating nodes in a graph. * Common methods include (but are not limited to) * Breadth-First Search (BFS) * Depth-First Search (DFS) * **Abstraction Levels** * In graph networks, different levels of abstraction can be used to simplify or complicate the representation of relationships. * **Neighbors** * In a graph, neighbors of a node are other nodes that are directly connected to it by an edge. * **Equivalence & Equality in Graphs** * Understanding when two nodes are considered equivalent or equal * This is not as straightforward as it may appear... it may involve complex logic beyond simple identity or value comparison. * **Recursion** * Some functions use recursion, which is a method of solving a problem where the solution depends on solutions to smaller instances of the same problem. * NOTE: This is not a graph networking concept but is important nonetheless --- `Point` Class | **Method** | **Purpose in Point Class** | **Description** | |-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------| | *(No specific methods)* | Inherits all behavior from Node without any modification. | Point is a basic entity in geometry without additional methods beyond those in Node. | ---
--- `Direction` Class | **Method** | **Purpose in Direction Class** | **Description** | |-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------| | *(No specific methods)* | Inherits all behavior from Node and represents a geometric direction. | Direction is used to represent the concept of direction in geometry without additional methods beyond those in Node. | ---
--- `Measure` Class | **Method** | **Purpose in Measure Class** | **Description** | |-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------| | *(No specific methods)* | Inherits all behavior from Node, specializing in geometric measures. | Measure represents various measurements like angles, lengths, etc., without additional methods beyond those in Node. | ---
--- `Length` Class | **Method** | **Purpose in Length Class** | **Description** | |-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------| | *(No specific methods)* | Inherits all behavior from Node, specializing in representing lengths.| Length represents lengths in geometry without additional methods beyond those in Node. | ---
--- `Value` Class | **Method** | **Purpose in Value Class** | **Description** | |-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------| | *(No specific methods)* | Inherits all behavior from Node, encapsulating a generic value. | Value is used in various contexts like ratios without additional methods beyond those in Node. | ---
--- `Line` Class | **Method** | **Purpose in Line Class** | **Description** | |-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------| | **`new_val`** | Creates a new Direction node associated with this Line. | Used to create a directional aspect for a line. | | **`why_coll`** | Explains why given points are collinear with this line. | Used to determine the collinearity of points with the line. | ---
--- `Segment` Class | **Method** | **Purpose in Segment Class** | **Description** | |-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------| | **`new_val`** | Creates a new Length node associated with this Segment. | Used to associate a length measure with a segment. | ---
--- `Circle` Class | **Method** | **Purpose in Circle Class** | **Description** | |-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------| | **`why_cyclic`** | Explains why given points are cyclic with respect to this circle. | Determines the cyclic nature of points with respect to the circle. | ---

Returns: Length: A new instance of the Length class. """ return Length() class Line(Node): """Node of type Line, representing a geometrical line. Inherits from Node and adds specific functionality for lines in geometry. A line is an infinitely long straight path with no thickness. NOTE: If it had a finite length it would be a 'Segment' """ def new_val(self) -> Direction: """Creates a new Direction instance. This method overrides the `new_val` method in the Node class, providing a specific implementation for Line, where the value associated with a line is its direction. Returns: Direction: A new instance of the Direction class. """ return Direction() def why_coll(self, points: list[Point], level: int = None) -> list[Any]: """Explains why a set of points are collinear with this line. This method is used to determine the reasons behind the collinearity of a set of points with this line. It checks at various levels of abstraction as defined by 'level'. Args: points (list[Point]): A list of Point instances to check for collinearity. level (int, optional): The level of abstraction for checking collinearity. Defaults to infinity. Returns: list[Any] or None: A list of reasons for collinearity, or None if no collinearity is found. """ # Default level is infinity if not specified. level = level or float('inf') # Create a list to hold groups of lines connected to each point. groups = [] for p in points: # Extract lines connected to point `p` with dependencies below the specified level. group = [l for l, d in self.edge_graph[p].items() if d is None or d.level < level] # If no group is formed, return None as collinearity cannot be established. if not group: return None groups.append(group) # Initialize a variable to hold the minimum set of dependencies that explain the collinearity. min_deps = None for line in groups[0]: # For each line, find equal groups and their dependencies. deps, others = line.why_equal_groups(groups[1:], level) if deps is None: continue # Skip if no dependencies are found. # Add dependencies to the list for each point-line pair. for p, o in zip(points, [line] + others): deps.append(self.edge_graph[p][o]) # Update min_deps if it's None or found dependencies are fewer. if min_deps is None or len(deps) < len(min_deps): min_deps = deps # If no minimal dependencies are found, return None. Otherwise, return the found dependencies. if min_deps is None: return None # Return the subset of deps (paths) that is not None return [d for d in min_deps if d is not None] class Circle(Node): """Node of type Circle, representing a geometrical circle. Inherits from Node and adds specific functionality for circles in geometry. A circle is a set of points in a plane that are all at a given distance (the radius) from a fixed point (the center). """ def why_cyclic(self, points: list[Point], level: int = None) -> list[Any]: """Explains why a set of points are cyclic with respect to this circle. Determines the reasons behind the cyclic nature (all points lie on the circumference) of a set of points with respect to this circle. Args: points (list[Point]): A list of Point instances to check for cyclic nature. level (int, optional): The level of abstraction for checking cyclic nature. Defaults to infinity. Returns: list[Any] or None: A list of reasons for cyclic nature, or None if it's not cyclic. """ # Default level is infinity if not specified. level = level or float('inf') # Create a list to hold groups of circles connected to each point. groups = [] for p in points: # Extract circles connected to point `p` with dependencies below the specified level. group = [c for c, d in self.edge_graph[p].items() if d is None or d.level < level] # If no group is formed, return None as the cyclic nature cannot be established. if not group: return None groups.append(group) # Initialize a variable to hold the minimum set of dependencies that explain the cyclic nature. min_deps = None for circle in groups[0]: # For each circle, find equal groups and their dependencies. deps, others = circle.why_equal_groups(groups[1:], level) if deps is None: continue # Skip if no dependencies are found. # Add dependencies to the list for each point-circle pair. for p, o in zip(points, [circle] + others): deps.append(self.edge_graph[p][o]) # Update min_deps if it's None or found dependencies are fewer. if min_deps is None or len(deps) < len(min_deps): min_deps = deps # If no minimal dependencies are found, return None. Otherwise, return the found dependencies. if min_deps is None: return None # Return the subset of deps (paths) that is not None return [d for d in min_deps if d is not None] class Angle(Node): """Node of type Angle, representing a geometrical angle. This class extends the Node class, providing a way to encapsulate a generic value. Example Usage: >>> value = Value() """ # Inherits all behavior from Node without any modification. pass def why_connect(*pairs: list[tuple[Node, Node]]) -> list[Any]: """ Finds reasons for connection between pairs of nodes. This function takes pairs of nodes and for each pair, it determines why they are connected in the graph. It leverages the `why_connect` method of the `Node` class. Args: pairs (list[tuple[Node, Node]]): A list of tuples, each containing two nodes for which the connection reason is to be found. Returns: list[Any]: A list containing the reasons for connection for each pair of nodes. Example Usage: >>> node1 = Node() >>> node2 = Node() >>> why_connect((node1, node2)) [connection_reason] """ # Initialize an empty list to store the results. result = [] # Iterate over each pair of nodes provided as input. for node1, node2 in pairs: # For each pair, call the 'why_connect' method on the first node (node1) # - pass the second node (arg) to find out the connection reason # - Append the result of 'why_connect' to the 'result' list. result += node1.why_connect(node2) # After processing all pairs, return the list of connection reasons. return result def is_equiv(x: Node, y: Node, level: int = None) -> bool: """ Determines if two nodes are equivalent at a certain level of abstraction. The function checks if two nodes, x and y, are equivalent. The level of abstraction for checking equivalence can be specified. If no level is given, it defaults to infinity, meaning it checks at all levels. Args: x (Node): The first node. y (Node): The second node. level (int, optional): The level of abstraction for the equivalence check. Defaults to None. Returns: bool: True if the nodes are equivalent at the specified level, False otherwise. Example Usage: >>> point1 = Point() >>> point2 = Point() >>> is_equiv(point1, point2) False """ # If the 'level' argument is None, set it to infinity. # - This indicates the check should consider all levels of abstraction. level = level or float('inf') # Call the 'why_equal' method on node 'x' with node 'y' and 'level'. # - The method returns None if they ARE NOT equivalent # - The method returns a non-None value if they ARE equivalent. # We then check this result and convert it into a boolean value return x.why_equal([y], level) is not None def is_equal(x: Node, y: Node, level: int = None) -> bool: """ Checks if two nodes are equal based on their values and equivalence. This function compares two nodes for equality. It first checks if they are the same instance, then verifies if their values (`_val` attributes) are not None and finally checks if their values are equal. If the values are equal, it additionally checks for their equivalence using `is_equiv`. Args: x (Node): The first node. y (Node): The second node. level (int, optional): The level of abstraction for equivalence check. Defaults to None. Returns: bool: True if the nodes are equal, False otherwise. Example Usage: >>> nodeA = Node() >>> nodeB = Node() >>> is_equal(nodeA, nodeB) False """ # First, check if the two nodes are exactly the same instance. # - If so they are equivalent (trivial case) if x == y: return True # Check if either of the nodes has a None value for '_val'. # - If so, the nodes cannot be considered equal, so return False. if x._val is None or y._val is None: return False # Compare the '_val' attributes of the nodes. # - If they are different, the nodes are not equal, so return False. if x.val != y.val: return False # If the '_val' attributes are the same... # We have to further check if the nodes are equivalent using 'is_equiv' # - This is a deeper check to see if they are considered equal # - It operates at a specific level of abstraction ('level'). return is_equiv(x._val, y._val, level) def why_equal(x: Node, y: Node, level: int = None) -> list[Any]: """ Determines the reasons for the equality of two nodes at a specified level of abstraction. This function is crucial for understanding why two nodes in the graph are considered equal. It checks for direct equality, and if not directly equal, it checks the equality of their values. Args: x (Node): The first node to compare. y (Node): The second node to compare. level (int, optional): The level of abstraction for checking equality. Defaults to None (all levels). Returns: list[Any] or None: A list of reasons for equality if they are equal; None otherwise. Example Usage: >>> node1 = Node() >>> node2 = Node() >>> why_equal(node1, node2) None # or [reasons] if they are equal """ # First, check if the two nodes are exactly the same instance. # - If so they are equivalent (trivial case) if x == y: return [] # Check if either node has a Falsey value # - If so, the nodes cannot be considered equal, so return None. if not x._val or not y._val: return None # Check if the values of the nodes are the same # - If so, they are equivalent. if x._val == y._val: return [] # If values are not the same, check for equality at a deeper level using 'why_equal'. return x._val.why_equal([y._val], level) def val_type(x: Node) -> Type[Node]: """ Determines the type of value associated with a given node. This function helps to find out what kind of value a node represents, such as direction, length, etc. Args: x (Node): The node whose value type is to be determined. Returns: Type[Node]: The type of value associated with the node. Example Usage: >>> node = Line() >>> val_type(node) """ # Determine the value type based on the node's class. # The function can be extended to include other node types and their associated value types. if isinstance(x, Line): # If 'x' is an instance of the Line class, return the Direction class. # This indicates that for a Line node, the associated value type is Direction. return Direction if isinstance(x, Segment): # If 'x' is an instance of the Segment class, return the Length class. # This indicates that for a Segment node, the associated value type is Length. return Length if isinstance(x, Angle): # If 'x' is an instance of the Angle class, return the Measure class. # This indicates that for an Angle node, the associated value type is Measure. return Measure if isinstance(x, Ratio): # If 'x' is an instance of the Ratio class, return the Value class. # This indicates that for a Ratio node, the associated value type is Value. return Value def name_map(struct: Any) -> Any: """ Recursively maps a data structure of nodes to their names. This utility function is useful for converting complex structures containing nodes into a more readable format by using the names of the nodes. Args: struct (Any): A data structure (like list, tuple, set, dict) containing nodes. Returns: Any: A similar structure where nodes are replaced with their names. Example Usage: >>> my_structure = [Node(name="A"), Node(name="B")] >>> name_map(my_structure) ["A", "B"] """ # Handle different types of data structures recursively. if isinstance(struct, list): # If 'struct' is a list, apply 'name_map' to each element in the list. # This creates a new list # - Each element is the result of applying 'name_map' to the original elements. return [name_map(x) for x in struct] elif isinstance(struct, tuple): # If 'struct' is a tuple, apply 'name_map' to each element in the tuple. # This creates a new tuple # - Each element is the result of applying 'name_map' to the original elements. return tuple([name_map(x) for x in struct]) elif isinstance(struct, set): # If 'struct' is a set, apply 'name_map' to each element in the set. # This creates a new set # - Each element is the result of applying 'name_map' to the original elements. return set([name_map(x) for x in struct]) elif isinstance(struct, dict): # If 'struct' is a dictionary, apply 'name_map' to both keys and values. # This creates a new dictionary # - Each key-value pair is the result of applying 'name_map' to the original pairs. return {name_map(key): name_map(value) for key, value in struct.items()} else: # If 'struct' is not a list, tuple, set, or dictionary, it's assumed to be a single node. # - We then Use 'getattr' to get the 'name' attribute of the node. # - If the node does not have a 'name', return an empty string. # - Otherwise we return the respective name from the 'name' attribute return getattr(struct, 'name', '') def bfs_backtrack( root: Node, leafs: list[Node], parent: dict[Node, Node] ) -> list[Any]: """ Backtracks from leaf nodes to the root node in a BFS traversal. Given a root node, a list of leaf nodes, and a parent mapping (as typically generated by a BFS traversal), this function reconstructs the path from each leaf node back to the root node. It stops backtracking when it reaches the root node or any node that has already been backtracked. Args: root (Node): The root node of the BFS traversal. leafs (list[Node]): A list of leaf nodes to backtrack from. parent (dict[Node, Node]): A dictionary mapping each node to its parent in the BFS traversal. Returns: list[Any]: A list containing the paths (in terms of edges) backtracked from the leafs to the root. Raises: None: This function does not explicitly raise any exceptions, but may implicitly raise if there are inconsistencies in the input data. Example Usage: >>> root_node = Node() >>> leaf_nodes = [Node(), Node()] >>> parent_map = {leaf_nodes[0]: root_node, leaf_nodes[1]: root_node} >>> bfs_backtrack(root_node, leaf_nodes, parent_map) [path1, path2] """ # Create a set 'backtracked' and add the 'root' node to it. # - This set will keep track of visited nodes during backtracking. backtracked = {root} # Initialize a list to store the dependencies (paths) found during backtracking. deps = [] # Iterate over each node in the 'leafs' list. for node in leafs: # If a leaf node is None, this is an invalid case, so return None. if node is None: return None # If the current node is already in the 'backtracked' set, skip to the next node. if node in backtracked: continue # If the current node does not have a parent in the 'parent' dictionary... # - This means there's a missing link in the path, so return None. if node not in parent: return None # Continue backtracking until break condition # - This condition is that a node is already in the 'backtracked' set while node not in backtracked: # Add the current node to the 'backtracked' set to mark it as visited. backtracked.add(node) # Append the dependency (edge) between the current node and its parent to the 'deps' list. deps.append(node.merge_graph[parent[node]]) # Move to the parent of the current node for the next iteration. node = parent[node] # After processing all leaf nodes, return the list of dependencies (paths) found. return deps def get_lines_thru_all(*points: list[Point]) -> list[Line]: """ Retrieves all lines that pass through a given set of points. This function is used to find all Line nodes in the graph that are connected to all the given Point nodes. It's a way to discover common lines shared by multiple points. Args: points (list[Point]): Variable number of Point instances. Returns: list[Line]: A list of Line instances that pass through all the given points. Example Usage: >>> point1, point2, point3 = Point(), Point(), Point() >>> lines = get_lines_thru_all(point1, point2, point3) """ # Default dictionary to count lines through each point. # - A default dict is one that when initialized assumes the value as defined (0 in this case) line2count = defaultdict(lambda: 0) # Get the set of all unique points points = set(points) # Iterate over each point (unique) and count the lines connected to each point. for p in points: for l in p.neighbors(Line): line2count[l] += 1 # Return the lines that are connected to all points. return [l for l, count in line2count.items() if count == len(points)] def line_of_and_why(points: list[Point], level: int = None) -> tuple[Line, list[Any]]: """ Determines the line on which given points are collinear and explains why. This function tries to find a Line node that all the given Point nodes are collinear with. Additionally, it provides the reasons for their collinearity. Args: points (list[Point]): A list of Point instances. level (int, optional): The level of abstraction for checking collinearity. Defaults to None. Returns: tuple[Line, list[Any]]: A tuple containing the Line instance and a list of reasons for collinearity, or (None, None) if no such line exists. Example Usage: >>> point1, point2, point3 = Point(), Point(), Point() >>> line, reasons = line_of_and_why([point1, point2, point3]) """ # Find all lines that pass through all given points. for l0 in get_lines_thru_all(*points): # Check equivalent lines for collinearity. for l in l0.equivs(): # Confirm all points are in the edge graph of the line. if all([p in l.edge_graph for p in points]): # Extract end points of the line and combine with the given points. x, y = l.points colls = list({x, y} | set(points)) # Determine the reasons for collinearity. why = l.why_coll(colls, level) # If there is a valid reason then we return the line and the reason if why is not None: return l, why # Return None if no line and reasons are found. return None, None def get_circles_thru_all(*points: list[Point]) -> list[Circle]: """ Retrieves all circles that pass through a given set of points. This function finds all Circle nodes in the graph that are connected to all the given Point nodes. It's used to identify common circles that encompass multiple points. Args: points (list[Point]): A variable number of Point instances. Returns: list[Circle]: A list of Circle instances that pass through all the given points. Example Usage: >>> point1, point2, point3 = Point(), Point(), Point() >>> circles = get_circles_thru_all(point1, point2, point3) """ # Initialize a dictionary to count the number of circles passing through each point. circle2count = defaultdict(lambda: 0) # Convert to set to ensure uniqueness of each point points = set(points) # Iterate through each point. for p in points: # For each circle connected to the point, increment its count. for c in p.neighbors(Circle): circle2count[c] += 1 # Return circles that pass through all points. return [c for c, count in circle2count.items() if count == len(points)] def circle_of_and_why(points: list[Point], level: int = None) -> tuple[Circle, list[Any]]: """ Determines the circle on which given points are concyclic and explains why. This function finds a Circle node that encompasses all the given Point nodes and provides reasons for their concyclicity (all points lying on the circumference of the circle). Args: points (list[Point]): A list of Point instances. level (int, optional): The level of abstraction for checking concyclicity. Defaults to None. Returns: tuple[Circle, list[Any]]: A tuple containing the Circle instance and a list of reasons for concyclicity, or (None, None) if no such circle exists. Example Usage: >>> point1, point2, point3 = Point(), Point(), Point() >>> circle, reasons = circle_of_and_why([point1, point2, point3]) """ # Find all circles that pass through all given points. for c0 in get_circles_thru_all(*points): # Check equivalent circles for concyclicity. for c in c0.equivs(): # Ensure all points are in the edge graph of the circle. if all([p in c.edge_graph for p in points]): # Create a list of unique points. cycls = list(set(points)) # Determine the reasons for concyclicity. why = c.why_cyclic(cycls, level) # If a valid reason is found then we return the circle and reason if why is not None: return c, why # Return None if no circle and reasons are found. return None, None def all_angles(d1: Direction, d2: Direction, level: int = None) -> tuple[Angle, list[Direction], list[Direction]]: """ Generates all angles formed by two directions up to a certain level of abstraction. Args: d1 (Direction): The first direction. d2 (Direction): The second direction. level (int, optional): The level of abstraction. Defaults to infinity. Yields: tuple[Angle, list[Direction], list[Direction]]: A tuple with an Angle instance and lists of equivalent directions for d1 and d2. Example Usage: >>> direction1, direction2 = Direction(), Direction() >>> for angle, d1_equivs, d2_equivs in all_angles(direction1, direction2): >>> print(angle, d1_equivs, d2_equivs) """ # Default level is infinity if not specified. level = level or float('inf') # Get all equivalent directions for d1 up to the specified level. d1s = d1.equivs_upto(level) # Get all equivalent directions for d2 up to the specified level. d2s = d2.equivs_upto(level) # Iterate over all angles connected to the representative direction of d1. for ang in d1.rep().neighbors(Angle): # Get the directions forming the angle. d1_, d2_ = ang._d # Yield the angle and equivalent directions if they match d1 and d2. if d1_ in d1s and d2_ in d2s: yield ang, d1s, d2s def all_ratios(d1, d2, level=None) -> tuple[Angle, list[Direction], list[Direction]]: """ Generates all ratios formed by two values up to a certain level of abstraction. Args: d1 (Node): The first value. d2 (Node): The second value. level (int, optional): The level of abstraction. Defaults to infinity. Yields: tuple[Angle, list[Direction], list[Direction]]: A tuple with a Ratio instance and lists of equivalent values for d1 and d2. Example Usage: >>> value1, value2 = Value(), Value() >>> for ratio, v1_equivs, v2_equivs in all_ratios(value1, value2): >>> print(ratio, v1_equivs, v2_equivs) """ level = level or float('inf') # Default level is infinity if not specified. d1s = d1.equivs_upto(level) # Get all equivalent values for d1 up to the specified level. d2s = d2.equivs_upto(level) # Get all equivalent values for d2 up to the specified level. # Iterate over all ratios connected to the representative value of d1. for rat in d1.rep().neighbors(Ratio): d1_, d2_ = rat._l # Get the values forming the ratio. # Yield the ratio and equivalent values if they match d1 and d2. if d1_ in d1s and d2_ in d2s: yield rat, d1s, d2s # This dictionary defines a ranking for different types of nodes. # - It's used to prioritize or differentiate between node types # - I'm not sure why yet... RANKING = { Point: 0, Line: 1, Segment: 2, Circle: 3, Direction: 4, Length: 5, Angle: 6, Ratio: 7, Measure: 8, Value: 9, }

5.2 PRETTY.PY FILE - THE PRETTY HELPER FUNCTIONS

Utilities for string manipulation in the DSL. # This dictionary maps single character symbols to their respective geometric meanings. # - Each key is a character that represents a geometric concept (like 'T' for perpendicular) # - The corresponding value is a string that describes the concept in a more readable format. MAP_SYMBOL = { 'T': 'perp', # Perpendicular 'P': 'para', # Parallel 'D': 'cong', # Congruent 'S': 'simtri', # Similar Triangles 'I': 'circle', # Circle 'M': 'midp', # Midpoint 'O': 'cyclic', # Concyclic points (lying on the same circle) 'C': 'coll', # Collinear '^': 'eqangle', # Equal Angle '/': 'eqratio', # Equal Ratio '%': 'eqratio', # Equal Ratio (alternative symbol) '=': 'contri', # Congruent Triangles 'X': 'collx', # Collinear (extended) 'A': 'acompute', # Angle computation 'R': 'rcompute', # Ratio computation 'Q': 'fixc', # Fixed constant 'E': 'fixl', # Fixed line 'V': 'fixb', # Fixed bisector 'H': 'fixt', # Fixed tangent 'Z': 'fixp', # Fixed point 'Y': 'ind', # Independent variable or parameter } def map_symbol(c: str) -> str: """ Maps a single character representing a geometric concept to a more readable string format. Args: c (str): A single character symbol representing a geometric concept. Returns: str: A more readable string representation of the geometric concept. Raises: KeyError: If the symbol `c` is not found in the MAP_SYMBOL dictionary. Example Usage: >>> map_symbol('T') 'perp' """ return MAP_SYMBOL[c] def map_symbol_inv(c: str) -> str: """ Maps a geometric concept in string format back to its corresponding single character symbol. Args: c (str): A string representing a geometric concept. Returns: str: The corresponding single character symbol. Raises: KeyError: If the string `c` does not have a corresponding symbol in the MAP_SYMBOL dictionary. Example Usage: >>> map_symbol_inv('perp') 'T' """ # This creates a reverse mapping of the MAP_SYMBOL dictionary # - i.e. the Keys become Values and viceaversa. return {v: k for k, v in MAP_SYMBOL.items()}[c] def _gcd(x: int, y: int) -> int: """ Computes the greatest common divisor (GCD) of two integers using the Euclidean algorithm. Args: x (int): The first integer. y (int): The second integer. Returns: int: The greatest common divisor of `x` and `y`. Example Usage: >>> _gcd(8, 12) 4 """ # The Euclidean algorithm iteratively applies the 'modulus' operation until y becomes zero. # - At that point, x holds the greatest common divisor. while y: x, y = y, x % y return x def simplify(n: int, d: int) -> tuple[int, int]: """ Simplifies a fraction by dividing both the numerator and denominator by their GCD. Args: n (int): The numerator of the fraction. d (int): The denominator of the fraction. Returns: tuple[int, int]: A tuple containing the simplified numerator and denominator. Raises: ZeroDivisionError: If the denominator `d` is zero. Example Usage: >>> simplify(8, 12) (2, 3) """ def pretty2r(a: str, b: str, c: str, d: str) -> str: """ Formats a set of four points for a RATIO (r) comparison. It ensures that the first point of each pair is not the common point in the RATIO (r) comparison. Args: a, b, c, d (str): Four points in a geometric context. Returns: str: A formatted string representing the ratio of segments AB:CD. Example Usage: >>> pretty2r('A', 'B', 'C', 'B') 'B A C B' """ # Swap a and b if b is the same as c or d. This is done to standardize the format for comparison. if b in (c, d): a, b = b, a # If a and d are the same, swap c and d to maintain the format. if a == d: c, d = d, c return f'{a} {b} {c} {d}' def pretty2a(a: str, b: str, c: str, d: str) -> str: """ Formats a set of four points for an ANGLE (a) comparison. It ensures that the first point of each pair is not the common point in the ANGLE (a) comparison. Args: a, b, c, d (str): Four points in a geometric context. Returns: str: A formatted string representing the angles AB and CD for comparison. Example Usage: >>> pretty2a('A', 'B', 'C', 'B') 'B A C B' """ # Swap a and b if b is the same as c or d. This is done to standardize the format for comparison. if b in (c, d): a, b = b, a # If a and d are the same, swap c and d to maintain the format. if a == d: c, d = d, c return f'{a} {b} {c} {d}' def pretty_angle(a: str, b: str, c: str, d: str) -> str: """ Formats a representation of an angle. Specifically for the case where the points form an angle (like ABC). It uses Unicode characters (\u2220) to represent the angle symbol. Args: a, b, c, d (str): Four points in a geometric context. Returns: str: A Unicode string representing the angle. For example, ABC or (AB-CD). Example Usage: >>> pretty_angle('A', 'B', 'C', 'D') '(ABC-BCD)' """ # Ensure the format aligns with the standard representation of an angle. # - i.e. We swap a and b if b is the same as c or d. # This is done to standardize the format for comparison. if b in (c, d): a, b = b, a # If a and d are the same, swap c and d to maintain the format. if a == d: c, d = d, c # Return the formatted angle, using the Unicode character for angle (). if a == c: # Simple angle like BAD. return f'\u2220{b}{a}{d}' # More complex angle representation like (AB-CD). return f'\u2220({a}{b}-{c}{d})' def pretty_nl(name: str, args: list[str]) -> str: """" Formats a geometric predicate into a natural language representation. Args: name (str): The name of the geometric predicate. args (list[str]): A list of arguments associated with the predicate. Returns: str: A natural language representation of the geometric predicate. Example Usage: >>> pretty_nl('coll', ['A', 'B', 'C']) 'A,B,C are collinear' Notes: - The function handles a variety of geometric predicates, each requiring a different format. - This function is central to converting raw geometric data into a form that's easily readable. """ # Handle the 'aconst' predicate, which represents a constant angle. if name == 'aconst': # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d, y = args # Format the angle using `pretty_angle`. return f'{pretty_angle(a, b, c, d)} = {y}' # Handle the 'rconst' predicate, which represents a constant ratio. if name == 'rconst': # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d, y = args # Format the ratio using `pretty2r`. return f'{a}{b}:{c}{d} = {y}' # Handle the 'acompute' predicate, which represents an angle computation. if name == 'acompute': # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d = args # Format the angle using `pretty_angle`. return f'{pretty_angle(a, b, c, d)}' # Handle the 'coll' predicate, which represents a collinear relationship. if name in ['coll', 'C']: # Format the collinear relationship as a comma-separated list with the words ' are collinear'. return '' + ','.join(args) + ' are collinear' # Handle the 'collx' predicate, which represents a collinear (extended) relationship. if name == 'collx': # Format the collinear relationship as a comma-separated list with the words ' are collinear'. return '' + ','.join(list(set(args))) + ' are collinear' # Handle the 'cyclic' predicate, which represents concyclic points (lying on the same circle) if name in ['cyclic', 'O']: # Format the cyclic relationship as a comma-separated list with the words ' are concyclic'. return '' + ','.join(args) + ' are concyclic' # Handle the 'midp' predicate, which represents a midpoint relationship. if name in ['midp', 'midpoint', 'M']: # Unpack the arguments. x, a, b = args # Format the midpoint relationship using a string. return f'{x} is midpoint of {a}{b}' # Handle the 'eqangle' (and 'eqangle6' amd '^' representations) predicate, which represents an equal angle relationship. if name in ['eqangle', 'eqangle6', '^']: # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h = args # Format the equal angle relationship using `pretty_angle`. return f'{pretty_angle(a, b, c, d)} = {pretty_angle(e, f, g, h)}' # Handle the 'eqratio' (and 'eqratio6' amd '/' representations) predicate, which represents an equal ratio # relationship. if name in ['eqratio', 'eqratio6', '/']: # Format the equal ratio relationship using string formatting return '{}{}:{}{} = {}{}:{}{}'.format(*args) # Handle the 'eqratio3' predicate, which represents an equal ratio relationship. if name == 'eqratio3': # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d, o, o = args # pylint: disable=redeclared-assigned-name # Format the equal ratio relationship as space delimited with prefix symbol 'S'. return f'S {o} {a} {b} {o} {c} {d}' # Handle the 'cong' (and 'D' representation) predicate, which represents a congruent relationship. if name in ['cong', 'D']: # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d = args # Return the congruent relationship as a string. return f'{a}{b} = {c}{d}' # Handle the 'perp' (and 'T' representation) predicate, which represents a perpendicular relationship. if name in ['perp', 'T']: # Handle the case where the predicate is an algebraic derivation. if len(args) == 2: # ab = 'd( ... )' ab, cd = args # Return the perpendicular relationship as a string with the angle symbol. return f'{ab} \u27c2 {cd}' # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d = args # Return the perpendicular relationship as a string with the angle symbol. return f'{a}{b} \u27c2 {c}{d}' # Handle the 'para' (and 'P' representation) predicate, which represents a parallel relationship. if name in ['para', 'P']: # Handle the case where the predicate is an algebraic derivation. if len(args) == 2: # ab = 'd( ... )' ab, cd = args # Return the parallel relationship as a string with the parallel symbol. return f'{ab} \u2225 {cd}' # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d = args # Return the parallel relationship as a string with the parallel symbol. return f'{a}{b} \u2225 {c}{d}' # Handle the 'simtri2' (and 'simtri' and 'simtri*' representations) predicate, which represents a similar if name in ['simtri2', 'simtri', 'simtri*']: # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, x, y, z = args # Return the similar triangle relationship as a string with the triangle symbol. return f'\u0394{a}{b}{c} is similar to \u0394{x}{y}{z}' # Handle the 'contri2' (and 'contri' and 'contri*' representations) predicate, which represents a congruent if name in ['contri2', 'contri', 'contri*']: # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, x, y, z = args # Return the congruent triangle relationship as a string with the triangle symbol. return f'\u0394{a}{b}{c} is congruent to \u0394{x}{y}{z}' # Handle the 'circle' (and 'I' representation) predicate, which represents a circle relationship. if name in ['circle', 'I']: # Unpack the arguments. o, a, b, c = args # Return the circle relationship as a string with the circle symbol. return f'{o} is the circumcenter of \\Delta {a}{b}{c}' # Handle the 'foot' predicate, which represents a foot relationship. if name == 'foot': # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d = args # Return the foot relationship as a string with the foot symbol. return f'{a} is the foot of {b} on {c}{d}' def pretty(txt: str) -> str: """ Formats a geometric predicate string into a more readable form, either as a symbol or in natural language. Args: txt (str): A string representing a geometric predicate and its arguments. Returns: str: A formatted string either in symbolic or natural language form. Example Usage: >>> pretty('coll A B C') 'C A B C are collinear' Notes: - This function decides whether to use symbolic or natural language format based on the predicate. - It's a higher-level formatter that either directly formats the string or delegates to `pretty_nl`. """ # Check if the input is a string and split it into words for further processing. if isinstance(txt, str): txt = txt.split(' ') # Extract the predicate name and its arguments. name, *args = txt # Handle various predicates, each requiring a unique formatting approach. if name == 'ind': # 'ind' represents an independent variable or parameter. return 'Y ' + ' '.join(args) # These predicates represent fixed geometric elements like constants, lines, bisectors, etc. if name in ['fixc', 'fixl', 'fixb', 'fixt', 'fixp']: # The arguments are joined with a space and prefixed with the corresponding symbol. return map_symbol_inv(name) + ' ' + ' '.join(args) # 'acompute' represents an angle computation. if name == 'acompute': # The arguments are joined with a space and prefixed with 'A'. return 'A ' + ' '.join(args) # 'rcompute' represents a ratio computation. if name == 'rcompute': # The arguments are joined with a space and prefixed with 'R'. return 'R ' + ' '.join(args) # 'aconst' represents a constant angle. if name == 'aconst': # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d, y = args # It uses `pretty2a` for formatting and is prefixed with '^'. return f'^ {pretty2a(a, b, c, d)} {y}' # 'rconst' represents a constant ratio. if name == 'rconst': # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d, y = args # It uses `pretty2r` for formatting and is prefixed with '/'. return f'/ {pretty2r(a, b, c, d)} {y}' # 'coll' represents a collinear relationship. if name == 'coll': # It's prefixed with 'C' and the arguments are joined with a space. return 'C ' + ' '.join(args) # 'collx' represents a collinear (extended) relationship. if name == 'collx': # It's prefixed with 'X' and the arguments are joined with a space. return 'X ' + ' '.join(args) # 'cyclic' represents a cyclic relationship. if name == 'cyclic': # It's prefixed with 'O' and the arguments are joined with a space. return 'O ' + ' '.join(args) # 'midp' represents a midpoint relationship. if name in ['midp', 'midpoint']: # Unpack the arguments. x, a, b = args # It's prefixed with 'M' and the arguments are joined with a space. return f'M {x} {a} {b}' # 'eqangle' (and 'eqangle6' and '^') represents an equal angle relationship. if name == 'eqangle': # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h = args # It uses `pretty2a` for formatting and is prefixed with '^'. return f'^ {pretty2a(a, b, c, d)} {pretty2a(e, f, g, h)}' # 'eqratio' (and 'eqratio6' and '/') represents an equal ratio relationship. if name == 'eqratio': # It uses `pretty2r` for formatting and is prefixed with '/'. a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h = args # Return the equal ratio relationship as a string with the ratio symbol. return f'/ {pretty2r(a, b, c, d)} {pretty2r(e, f, g, h)}' # 'eqratio3' represents an equal ratio relationship. if name == 'eqratio3': # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d, o, o = args # pylint: disable=redeclared-assigned-name # Return the equal ratio relationship as a string with the ratio symbol. return f'S {o} {a} {b} {o} {c} {d}' # 'cong' (and 'D') represents a congruent relationship. if name == 'cong': # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d = args # Return the congruent relationship as a string with the congruent symbol. return f'D {a} {b} {c} {d}' # 'perp' (and 'T') represents a perpendicular relationship. if name == 'perp': # Handle the case where the predicate is an algebraic derivation. if len(args) == 2: # ab = 'd( ... )' ab, cd = args # Return the perpendicular relationship as a string with the perpendicular symbol. return f'T {ab} {cd}' # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d = args # Return the perpendicular relationship as a string with the perpendicular symbol. return f'T {a} {b} {c} {d}' # 'para' (and 'P') represents a parallel relationship. if name == 'para': # Handle the case where the predicate is an algebraic derivation. if len(args) == 2: # ab = 'd( ... )' ab, cd = args # Return the parallel relationship as a string with the parallel symbol. return f'P {ab} {cd}' # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d = args # Return the parallel relationship as a string with the parallel symbol. return f'P {a} {b} {c} {d}' # 'simtri2' (and 'simtri' and 'simtri*') represents a similar triangle relationship. if name in ['simtri2', 'simtri', 'simtri*']: # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, x, y, z = args # Return the similar triangle relationship as a string with the triangle symbol. return f'S {a} {b} {c} {x} {y} {z}' # 'contri2' (and 'contri' and 'contri*') represents a congruent triangle relationship. if name in ['contri2', 'contri', 'contri*']: # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, x, y, z = args # Return the congruent triangle relationship as a string with the triangle symbol. return f'= {a} {b} {c} {x} {y} {z}' # 'circle' (and 'I') represents a circle relationship. if name == 'circle': # Unpack the arguments. o, a, b, c = args # Return the circle relationship as a string with the circle symbol. return f'I {o} {a} {b} {c}' # 'foot' represents a foot relationship. if name == 'foot': # Unpack the arguments. a, b, c, d = args # Return the foot relationship as a string with the foot symbol. return f'F {a} {b} {c} {d}' # If the predicate is not handled above, we format it as a space-delimited string. return ' '.join(txt)
