Extracting the points that define the segments for ratio comparison. a, b, c, d, m, n, p, q = self.args # Getting the segments ab, cd, mn, pq from the geometry context 'g'. ab = g._get_segment(a, b) cd = g._get_segment(c, d) mn = g._get_segment(m, n) pq = g._get_segment(p, q) # Check if any of these segments are undefined, possibly due to overlapping points. if ab is None or cd is None or mn is None or pq is None: # If any pair of points defining a segment are the same, then we are looking at congruence, not ratio. if {a, b} == {m, n}: # Create a congruence dependency and find its reasoning. d = Dependency('cong', [c, d, p, q], None, level) self.why = [d.why_me_or_cache(g, level)] # Similar checks for other combinations of points. if {a, b} == {c, d}: d = Dependency('cong', [p, q, m, n], None, level) self.why = [d.why_me_or_cache(g, level)] if {c, d} == {p, q}: d = Dependency('cong', [a, b, m, n], None, level) self.why = [d.why_me_or_cache(g, level)] if {p, q} == {m, n}: d = Dependency('cong', [a, b, c, d], None, level) self.why = [d.why_me_or_cache(g, level)] return # Exit if any segments are undefined. # If all segments are well-defined, check if their ratios are equal. if ab._val and cd._val and mn._val and pq._val: self.why = why_eqratio(ab._val, cd._val, mn._val, pq._val, level) # If no specific reason for equal ratios is found, explore other possibilities. if self.why is None: self.why = [] # Initialize an empty list for reasons. # Check for direct equality of segments which would imply equal ratios. if (ab == cd and mn == pq) or (ab == mn and cd == pq): self.why += [] # No additional dependencies are needed in this case. elif ab == mn: # If segments ab and mn are equal, explore reasons for their equality and add to 'why'. self.why += maybe_make_equal_pairs(a, b, c, d, m, n, p, q, ab, mn, g, level) elif cd == pq: # If segments cd and pq are equal, explore reasons for their equality and add to 'why'. self.why += maybe_make_equal_pairs(c, d, a, b, p, q, m, n, cd, pq, g, level) elif ab == cd: # If segments ab and cd are equal, explore reasons for their equality and add to 'why'. self.why += maybe_make_equal_pairs(a, b, m, n, c, d, p, q, ab, cd, g, level) elif mn == pq: # If segments mn and pq are equal, explore reasons for their equality and add to 'why'. self.why += maybe_make_equal_pairs(m, n, a, b, p, q, c, d, mn, pq, g, level) # Check if segments are parallel as a possible reason for equal ratios. if g.is_equal(ab, mn) or g.is_equal(cd, pq): # Create and resolve dependencies for parallel lines (ab//mn or cd//pq). dep1 = Dependency('para', [a, b, m, n], None, level) dep1.why_me(g, level) dep2 = Dependency('para', [c, d, p, q], None, level) dep2.why_me(g, level) self.why += [dep1, dep2] if g.is_equal(ab, cd) or g.is_equal(mn, pq): # Create and resolve dependencies for parallel lines (ab//cd or mn//pq). dep1 = Dependency('para', [a, b, c, d], None, level) dep1.why_me(g, level) dep2 = Dependency('para', [m, n, p, q], None, level) dep2.why_me(g, level) self.why += [dep1, dep2] # Finally, if all else fails, re-check for equal angles as a last resort. if ab._val and cd._val and mn._val and pq._val: self.why = why_eqangle(ab._val, cd._val, mn._val, pq._val, level) # These are different types of geometric dependencies. elif self.name in ['diff', 'npara', 'nperp', 'ncoll', 'sameside']: # For these types, currently, no additional dependencies are determined. # - This might represent cases where the dependency is either direct or not yet implemented. self.why = [] # Handling the case of similar triangles. elif self.name == 'simtri': # Extracts the points defining the two triangles. a, b, c, x, y, z = self.args # Creates a dependency for equal angles between the two triangles. # - i.e. angle at 'a' in the first triangle should be equal to the angle at 'x' in the second triangle. dep1 = Dependency('eqangle', [a, b, a, c, x, y, x, z], '', level) dep1.why_me(g, level) # Determines why these angles are equal. # Similarly, this checks for equality of another pair of angles. dep2 = Dependency('eqangle', [b, a, b, c, y, x, y, z], '', level) dep2.why_me(g, level) # Assigns a rule name for this type of dependency. self.rule_name = 'r34' # Records these dependencies. self.why = [dep1, dep2] # Handling the case of congruent triangles. elif self.name == 'contri': # Extracts the points defining the two triangles. a, b, c, x, y, z = self.args # Checks for congruence (equality of length) between corresponding sides (ab w/ xy) of the triangles. dep1 = Dependency('cong', [a, b, x, y], '', level) # Determines why these segments (ab w/ xy) are congruent. dep1.why_me(g, level) # Checks for congruence (equality of length) between corresponding sides (bc w/ yz) of the triangles. dep2 = Dependency('cong', [b, c, y, z], '', level) # Determines why these segments (bc w/ yz) are congruent. dep2.why_me(g, level) # Checks for congruence (equality of length) between corresponding sides (ca w/ zx) of the triangles. dep3 = Dependency('cong', [c, a, z, x], '', level) # Determines why these segments (ca w/ zx) are congruent. dep3.why_me(g, level) # Assigns a rule name for this type of dependency. self.rule_name = 'r32' # Records these dependencies. self.why = [dep1, dep2, dep3] # This case represents 'independence'. # - This appears to be a placeholder for dependencies that don't need further explanation or are considered axiomatic. elif self.name == 'ind': # No action is taken for 'independent' dependencies. pass # Handling the case for a constant angle. elif self.name == 'aconst': # Extracts points and the angle of interest. a, b, c, d, ang0 = self.args # Gets the value of the angle. measure = ang0._val # Iterates over angles neighboring the given angle in the geometric context. for ang in measure.neighbors(gm.Angle): # Skips this angle if it's the same angle as the original. if ang == ang0: continue # Extracts line objects from the neighboring angle. d1, d2 = ang._d l1, l2 = d1._obj, d2._obj (a1, b1), (c1, d1) = l1.points, l2.points # Checks if lines are parallel or collinear. # - If not than we skip this angle if not g.check_para_or_coll([a, b, a1, b1]) or not g.check_para_or_coll([c, d, c1, d1]): continue # Clears previous reasons, preparing to record new ones. self.why = [] # For each set of arguments, checks if they are collinear. for args in [(a, b, a1, b1), (c, d, c1, d1)]: if g.check_coll(args): # If they are collinear and involve more than two unique points if len(set(args)) > 2: dep = Dependency('coll', args, None, None) # A collinearity dependency is added. self.why.append(dep.why_me_or_cache(g, level)) else: # If they are not collinear dep = Dependency('para', args, None, None) # a parallel dependency is added. self.why.append(dep.why_me_or_cache(g, level)) # Adds reasons explaining the equality of the given angle with its neighboring angles. self.why += gm.why_equal(ang, ang0) # Exits after processing the first relevant angle. break # Handling the case for a constant ratio. elif self.name == 'rconst': # Extracts points and the ratio of interest. a, b, c, d, rat0 = self.args # Gets the value of the ratio. val = rat0._val # Iterates over ratios neighboring the given ratio in the geometric context. for rat in val.neighbors(gm.Ratio): # If this ratio is the same ratio as the original we skip it if rat == rat0: continue # Extracts line objects from the neighboring ratio. l1, l2 = rat._l s1, s2 = l1._obj, l2._obj (a1, b1), (c1, d1) = list(s1.points), list(s2.points) # Checks if corresponding segments are congruent # - If not, then we skip this ratio if not g.check_cong([a, b, a1, b1]) or not g.check_cong([c, d, c1, d1]): continue # Clears previous reasons, preparing to record new ones. self.why = [] # For each set of arguments for args in [(a, b, a1, b1), (c, d, c1, d1)]: if len(set(args)) > 2: dep = Dependency('cong', args, None, None) # Add a congruency dependency self.why.append(dep.why_me_or_cache(g, level)) # Adds reasons explaining the equality of the given ratio with its neighboring ratios. self.why += gm.why_equal(rat, rat0) # Exits after processing the first relevant ratio. break # This case handles unrecognized dependency names. else: # Raises an error if the dependency name is not recognized. raise ValueError('Not recognized', self.name) def hashed(self, rename: bool = False) -> tuple[str, ...]: """ Creates a hash-like tuple representation for the Dependency object. Args: rename (bool, optional): If True, use alternative names for the points. Returns: tuple[str, ...]: A tuple representing the hashed value of the dependency. Example Usage: >>> dep = Dependency('line', [Point('A'), Point('B')], 'rule1', 1) >>> dep.hashed() ('line', 'A', 'B') Note: This method is used for caching and identifying unique dependencies. """ # Utilize the hashed function to create the tuple. return hashed(self.name, self.args, rename=rename) class EmptyDependency: """ Represents an initially empty geometric dependency that can be filled and extended. This class is used as a starting point for constructing more complex dependencies in geometric reasoning. It allows for incremental building up of a dependency from simpler components. Attributes: level (int): The level of complexity or derivation for the dependency. rule_name (str): Name of the rule associated with the dependency, if any. empty (bool): A flag indicating whether the dependency is empty. why (list[Dependency]): A list of Dependency objects that this one depends on. trace (Any): Optional attribute for debugging or tracing the dependency. Methods: populate: Fills the empty dependency with details. copy: Creates a deep copy of the empty dependency. extend: Adds a new dependency to the list. extend_many: Adds multiple new dependencies to the list. """ def __init__(self, level: int, rule_name: str): """ Initializes an EmptyDependency object. Args: level (int): The complexity level for the dependency. rule_name (str): The rule name associated with this dependency, if applicable. The object starts with no dependencies (empty list) and is marked as empty. """ # Complexity level of the dependency. self.level = level # Rule name, defaulting to an empty string if not provided. self.rule_name = rule_name or '' # Initially marked as empty. self.empty = True # Initializes with no dependencies. self.why = [] # Optional tracing information, initially None. self.trace = None def populate(self, name: str, args: list[gm.Point]) -> Dependency: """ Populates the current empty dependency with a specific dependency. Args: name (str): The name of the dependency to be populated with. args (list[gm.Point]): The points or elements involved in the dependency. Returns: Dependency: A Dependency object populated with the given details. Example Usage: >>> empty_dep = EmptyDependency(level=1, rule_name='some_rule') >>> populated_dep = empty_dep.populate('line', [Point('A'), Point('B')]) # populated_dep is now a Dependency object representing a line with points 'A', 'B'. """ # Create the dependency from the provided information dep = Dependency(name, args, self.rule_name, self.level) # Inherit trace information from the empty dependency. dep.trace2 = self.trace # Copies the 'why' list to the new dependency. dep.why = list(self.why) return dep def copy(self) -> EmptyDependency: """ Creates a deep copy of the current EmptyDependency object. Returns: EmptyDependency: A new EmptyDependency object that is a copy of the current one. Example Usage: >>> original_empty_dep = EmptyDependency(level=1, rule_name='some_rule') >>> copied_empty_dep = original_empty_dep.copy() # copied_empty_dep is a separate instance with the same data as original_empty_dep. """ # Initialize a new EmptyDependency other = EmptyDependency(self.level, self.rule_name) # Maps the 'why' over to the new EmptyDependency other.why = list(self.why) return other def extend( self, g: Any, name0: str, args0: list[gm.Point], name: str, args: list[gm.Point], ) -> EmptyDependency: """ Extends the current dependency with a new one. This method adds a new dependency to the existing list of dependencies. Args: g (Any): The geometric context or environment. name0 (str): The name of the initial dependency. args0 (list[gm.Point]): The points involved in the initial dependency. name (str): The name of the new dependency to be added. args (list[gm.Point]): The points involved in the new dependency. Returns: EmptyDependency: An updated EmptyDependency object with the new dependency added. Example Usage: >>> current_dep = EmptyDependency(level=1, rule_name='some_rule') >>> extended_dep = current_dep.extend(geometry_context, 'line', [Point('A'), Point('B')], 'para', [Point('C'), Point('D')]) # extended_dep now includes dependencies for a line (AB) and parallelism (CD). """ # Populates the current dependency with the initial dependency details. dep0 = self.populate(name0, args0) # Creates a new EmptyDependency object. deps = EmptyDependency(level=self.level, rule_name=None) # Adds the new dependency to the list. dep = Dependency(name, args, None, deps.level) deps.why = [dep0, dep.why_me_or_cache(g, None)] return deps def extend_many( self, g: Any, name0: str, args0: list[gm.Point], name_args: list[tuple[str, list[gm.Point]]], ) -> EmptyDependency: """ Extends the current dependency with multiple new dependencies. This method allows adding several new dependencies at once. Args: g (Any): The geometric context or environment. name0 (str): The name of the initial dependency. args0 (list[gm.Point]): The points involved in the initial dependency. name_args (list[tuple[str, list[gm.Point]]]): A list of tuples, each containing a dependency name and its associated points. Returns: EmptyDependency: An updated EmptyDependency object with the new dependencies added. Example Usage: >>> current_dep = EmptyDependency(level=1, rule_name='some_rule') >>> name_args = [('para', [Point('C'), Point('D')]), ('coll', [Point('E'), Point('F')])] >>> extended_dep = current_dep.extend_many(geometry_context, 'line', [Point('A'), Point('B')], name_args) # extended_dep now includes dependencies for a line (AB), parallelism (CD), and collinearity (EF). """ # Return the current dependency if no new dependencies are provided. if not name_args: return self # Populates the current dependency with the initial dependency details. dep0 = self.populate(name0, args0) # Creates a new EmptyDependency object. deps = EmptyDependency(level=self.level, rule_name=None) # Adds the initial dependency to the list. deps.why = [dep0] # Iterates over each new dependency and adds them to the list along with the 'why' for name, args in name_args: dep = Dependency(name, args, None, deps.level) deps.why += [dep.why_me_or_cache(g, None)] return deps

5.9 PROBLEM.PY FILE - THE SPECIFIC/COMPLEX FUNCTIONS

def why_eqratio( d1: gm.Direction, d2: gm.Direction, d3: gm.Direction, d4: gm.Direction, level: int, ) -> list[Dependency]: """Determines the reasons for equality of two geometric ratios. This function is used in the context of geometric reasoning to explain why two ratios, formed by pairs of directions, are equal. It explores all combinations of equivalent ratios and finds the minimal explanation for their equality. Args: d1 (gm.Direction): The first direction in the first ratio. d2 (gm.Direction): The second direction in the first ratio. d3 (gm.Direction): The first direction in the second ratio. d4 (gm.Direction): The second direction in the second ratio. level (int): The level of abstraction for the reasoning. Returns: list[Dependency]: A list of Dependency objects representing the reasons for the equality of the two ratios. Example Usage: # Assuming d1, d2, d3, d4 are gm.Direction instances and 'level' is set. >>> reasons = why_eqratio(d1, d2, d3, d4, level) """ # Generate all possible equivalent ratios for the first and second pairs of directions. all12 = list(gm.all_ratios(d1, d2, level)) all34 = list(gm.all_ratios(d3, d4, level)) # Initialize a variable to keep track of the minimal explanation for ratio equality. min_why = None # Iterate through each combination of equivalent ratios from the first and second pairs. for ang12, d1s, d2s in all12: for ang34, d3s, d4s in all34: # Check if these two ratios are equal and if so why why0 = gm.why_equal(ang12, ang34, level) # Skip to the next combination if these two are not equal. if why0 is None: continue # Get the directions involved in the ratios d1_, d2_ = ang12._l d3_, d4_ = ang34._l # Backtrack to find the path of dependencies for each direction involved in the ratios. why1 = gm.bfs_backtrack(d1, [d1_], d1s) why2 = gm.bfs_backtrack(d2, [d2_], d2s) why3 = gm.bfs_backtrack(d3, [d3_], d3s) why4 = gm.bfs_backtrack(d4, [d4_], d4s) # Compile all reasons (dependencies) for the equality of these ratios. why = why0 + why1 + why2 + why3 + why4 # Update the minimal explanation if the current explanation is more concise. if min_why is None or len(why) < len(min_why[0]): min_why = why, ang12, ang34, why0, why1, why2, why3, why4 # If no explanation is found, return None. if min_why is None: return None # Extract from the minimal explanation the involved dependancies (whys), angles and directions. _, ang12, ang34, why0, why1, why2, why3, why4 = min_why # If the original and compared directions are the same, return the reasons for their equality. d1_, d2_ = ang12._l d3_, d4_ = ang34._l if d1 == d1_ and d2 == d2_ and d3 == d3_ and d4 == d4_: return why0 # Extract the points for each direction to create dependencies. (a_, b_), (c_, d_) = d1_._obj.points, d2_._obj.points (e_, f_), (g_, h_) = d3_._obj.points, d4_._obj.points # Initialize the list of dependencies deps = [] # If reasons for equality exist, create and append a Dependency object. if why0: dep = Dependency('eqratio', [a_, b_, c_, d_, e_, f_, g_, h_], '', level) dep.why = why0 deps.append(dep) # Iterate through each set of points and append necessary dependencies (congruent). (a, b), (c, d) = d1._obj.points, d2._obj.points (e, f), (g, h) = d3._obj.points, d4._obj.points for why, (x, y), (x_, y_) in zip( [why1, why2, why3, why4], # reason (or None) [(a, b), (c, d), (e, f), (g, h)], # pair of points (1) [(a_, b_), (c_, d_), (e_, f_), (g_, h_)], # pair of points (2) ): if why: dep = Dependency('cong', [x, y, x_, y_], '', level) dep.why = why deps.append(dep) # Return the list of dependencies explaining the equality of the ratios. return deps def why_eqangle( d1: gm.Direction, d2: gm.Direction, d3: gm.Direction, d4: gm.Direction, level: int, verbose: bool = False, ) -> list[Dependency]: """Determines the reasons for equality of two geometric angles. This function explains why two angles, formed by pairs of directions, are equal. It compares all combinations of equivalent angles and determines the minimal explanation for their equality. Args: d1, d2 (gm.Direction): Directions forming the first angle. d3, d4 (gm.Direction): Directions forming the second angle. level (int): The level of abstraction for the reasoning. verbose (bool, optional): If true, provides more detailed explanation. Defaults to False. Returns: list[Dependency]: A list of Dependency objects representing the reasons for the equality of the two angles. Example Usage: # Assuming d1, d2, d3, d4 are gm.Direction instances and 'level' is set. >>> reasons = why_eqangle(d1, d2, d3, d4, level) """ # Generate all possible equivalent angles for the first and second pairs of directions. all12 = list(gm.all_angles(d1, d2, level)) all34 = list(gm.all_angles(d3, d4, level)) # Initialize a variable to keep track of the minimal explanation for angle equality. min_why = None # Iterate through each combination of equivalent angles from the first and second pairs. for ang12, d1s, d2s in all12: for ang34, d3s, d4s in all34: # Check if these two angles are equal. why0 = gm.why_equal(ang12, ang34, level) # Skip to the next combination if these two are not equal. if why0 is None: continue # Backtrack to find the path of dependencies for each direction involved in the angles. d1_, d2_ = ang12._d d3_, d4_ = ang34._d why1 = gm.bfs_backtrack(d1, [d1_], d1s) why2 = gm.bfs_backtrack(d2, [d2_], d2s) why3 = gm.bfs_backtrack(d3, [d3_], d3s) why4 = gm.bfs_backtrack(d4, [d4_], d4s) # Compile all reasons (dependencies) for the equality of these angles. why = why0 + why1 + why2 + why3 + why4 # Update the minimal explanation if the current explanation is more concise. if min_why is None or len(why) < len(min_why[0]): min_why = why, ang12, ang34, why0, why1, why2, why3, why4 # If no explanation is found, return None. if min_why is None: return None # Extract from the minimal explanation the involved dependancies (whys), angles and directions. _, ang12, ang34, why0, why1, why2, why3, why4 = min_why why0 = gm.why_equal(ang12, ang34, level) d1_, d2_ = ang12._d d3_, d4_ = ang34._d # If the original and compared directions are the same, return the reasons for their equality. if d1 == d1_ and d2 == d2_ and d3 == d3_ and d4 == d4_: return (d1_, d2_, d3_, d4_), why0 # Extract the points for each direction to create dependencies. (a_, b_), (c_, d_) = d1_._obj.points, d2_._obj.points (e_, f_), (g_, h_) = d3_._obj.points, d4_._obj.points deps = [] # If reasons for equality exist, create and append a Dependency object. if why0: dep = Dependency('eqangle', [a_, b_, c_, d_, e_, f_, g_, h_], '', None) dep.why = why0 deps.append(dep) # Iterate through each set of points and append necessary dependencies. # We are iterating over a combined sequence of various elements: # 1. 'why1' to 'why4' are the reasons for the equality of the directions. # 2. 'd1' to 'd4' are the original direction objects. # 3. '(a, b)' to '(g, h)' are point pairs defining the original directions. # 4. 'd1_' to 'd4_' are the resultant direction objects after backtracking. # 5. '(a_, b_)' to '(g_, h_)' are point pairs defining the resultant directions. (a, b), (c, d) = d1._obj.points, d2._obj.points (e, f), (g, h) = d3._obj.points, d4._obj.points for why, d_xy, (x, y), d_xy_, (x_, y_) in zip( [why1, why2, why3, why4], [d1, d2, d3, d4], [(a, b), (c, d), (e, f), (g, h)], [d1_, d2_, d3_, d4_], [(a_, b_), (c_, d_), (e_, f_), (g_, h_)], ): # Extract the actual line (or segment) objects associated with the directions. xy, xy_ = d_xy._obj, d_xy_._obj # Check if there are valid reasons ('why') for the equality of directions. if why: # Determine the type of geometric relationship: # - If the original and resultant lines (segments) are the same, we use 'collx'. # - 'collx' implies an extended collinearity # - Otherwise, we infer that they are parallel, using 'para'. # - 'para' implies parallelism. if xy == xy_: name = 'collx' else: name = 'para' # Create a Dependency object to encapsulate this geometric relationship. # - The Dependency object takes: # - the name ('collx' or 'para') # - the points involved, # - an empty string for the rule name # - and the level of abstraction. dep = Dependency(name, [x_, y_, x, y], '', None) # Assign the reasons ('why') to this Dependency object. dep.why = why # Append the Dependency object to the list of dependencies ('deps'). deps.append(dep) # Return the list of dependencies explaining the equality of the angles. return (d1_, d2_, d3_, d4_), deps # This constant represents a default rule name used in the context of geometric dependencies. # - It's a placeholder/identifier for a basic rule in the geometric reasoning system. CONSTRUCTION_RULE = 'c0' def maybe_make_equal_pairs( a: gm.Point, b: gm.Point, c: gm.Point, d: gm.Point, m: gm.Point, n: gm.Point, p: gm.Point, q: gm.Point, ab: gm.Line, mn: gm.Line, g: Any, level: int, ) -> list[Dependency]: """Generates dependencies if certain line pairs are equal. This function creates dependencies based on the equality of geometric lines. It's used in geometric reasoning to infer dependencies from equal line segments or directions. Args: a, b, c, d, m, n, p, q (gm.Point): Points involved in the line segments. ab, mn (gm.Line): Line segments or directions to compare for equality. g (Any): Geometric context or environment. level (int): The level of abstraction for reasoning. Returns: list[Dependency]: A list of dependencies if the line pairs are equal, otherwise an empty list. Example Usage: # Assuming the points and lines are defined and 'level' is set. >>> dependencies = maybe_make_equal_pairs(a, b, c, d, m, n, p, q, ab, mn, g, level) Notes: Make a-b:c-d==m-n:p-q in case a-b==m-n or c-d==p-q. """ if ab != mn: return why = [] eqname = 'para' if isinstance(ab, gm.Line) else 'cong' colls = [a, b, m, n] if len(set(colls)) > 2 and eqname == 'para': dep = Dependency('collx', colls, None, level) dep.why_me(g, level) why += [dep] dep = Dependency(eqname, [c, d, p, q], None, level) dep.why_me(g, level) why += [dep] return why def compare_fn(dep: Dependency) -> tuple[Dependency, str]: """A helper function for sorting dependencies. This function is used as a key function in sorting dependencies. It creates a tuple from a dependency and its string representation, used for comparison. Args: dep (Dependency): A dependency object. Returns: tuple[Dependency, str]: A tuple with the dependency and its string representation. Example Usage: # Assuming 'deps' is a list of Dependency objects. >>> sorted_deps = sorted(deps, key=compare_fn) """ return (dep, pt.pretty(dep)) def sort_deps(deps: list[Dependency]) -> list[Dependency]: """Sorts a list of Dependency objects. This function sorts dependencies based on a custom sorting function, `compare_fn`. It's useful for organizing or prioritizing dependencies in geometric reasoning. Args: deps (list[Dependency]): A list of Dependency objects. Returns: list[Dependency]: A sorted list of Dependency objects. Example Usage: # Assuming 'deps' is a list of Dependency objects. >>> sorted_deps = sort_deps(deps) """ return sorted(deps, key=compare_fn)
